info.game_comments:
2003 College Championship quarterfinal game 5.
From Yale University.

(1, 1).clue: In 1543 this Polish astronomer wrote, "Finally we shall place the sun himself at the center of the universe"

(2, 1).clue: In the classic comedy "Horse Feathers", Harpo & Chico play football & he plays a college president

(3, 1).clue: At Wrexham in this country in west Britain, you can see Eli Yale's grave and a church that's replicated on Yale's campus

(4, 1).clue: Pick up one of the new twenties that came out in 1849 & you'd be holding a coin with about an ounce of this

(5, 1).clue: Today it would be a Perrier carrier

(1, 2).clue: On July 19, 1988 he said, "We are all precious in God's sight -- the real rainbow coalition"

(2, 2).clue: In "Campus Man", a student at this Tempe school markets a male calendar featuring his hunky roommate

(3, 2).clue: 1 of the 3 countries bordering Sudan whose names start with an "E"

(4, 2).clue: Ralph Basham, director of this agency that foils counterfeiters, helped unveil the new $20 bill in 2003

(5, 2).clue: You can't tell by looking at it, but it has a golden fleece

(1, 3).clue: This document ends, "We mutually pledge to each other our lives, our fortunes, and our sacred honor"

(2, 3).clue: Jim's parents come to his college & walk in on him & his girlfriend in the second film in this "tasty" series

(3, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew presents from Honolulu.)  The statue of Kamehameha was cast in this city, just like the Statue of Liberty, & around the same time

(4, 3).clue: The new bill has anti-forgery microprinting under this person's signature on the left of the bill

(5, 3).clue: As a car, this constellation with more than a dozen stars has a 5-star front crash test rating

(6, 3).clue: In grammar, it's a part of speech that modifies a noun

(1, 4).clue: Truman said that he fired this man "because he wouldn't respect the authority of the President"

(2, 4).clue: Will Ferrell tries to recapture the fun of his college days (& even goes streaking) in this 2003 comedy

(3, 4).clue: It's named for Lady Penh, who found a bronze Buddha there

(4, 4).clue: The new 20 has added peach & blue to these 2 ink colors, the main ones in most U.S. currency

(5, 4).clue: This sign may or may not be pictured with a woman holding it

(6, 4).clue: General term for an animal that eats other animals

(1, 5).clue: In 1798 he told his troops in Africa, "From the summit of yonder pyramids forty centuries look down upon you"

(2, 5).clue: As a first-year student at NYU, Matthew Broderick meets up with a big lizard & a big mobster type in this comedy

(3, 5).clue: If your bags bear a "KUL" airport code, they're headed for the capital of this Asian country

(4, 5).clue: The new note features 2 more of these symbols of freedom for a total of 3

(6, 5).clue: It can mean a temperamental woman or an operatic prima donna

(1, 1).clue: When the Picts were a menace, the Angles & these people first came to help de-Pict Britain

(2, 1).clue: In the summer of 2003, you could have seen Melanie Griffith in "Chicago" & this husband of hers in "Nine"

(3, 1).clue: 1955's "East of Eden" launched the iconic status of this actor

(4, 1).clue: "Tempus Fugit" means this, & not just when you're having fun

(5, 1).clue: Sal Paradise & Dean Moriarty take a series of coast-to-coast trips in this Beat book

(6, 1).clue: Boston Ivy's scientific name. P. Tricuspidata indicates that it has leaves with this many lobes

(1, 2).clue: This city, a center of learning in Egypt, started to decline after the murder there of Hypatia, a female philosopher

(2, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew presents from the St. James Theater in New York City.)  "Springtime for Hitler" is the musical-within-a-musical in this Broadway blockbuster

(3, 2).clue: At this southern university, Dean Smith coached Sam Perkins, James Worthy & Michael Jordan

(4, 2).clue: When you're out shopping, remember "caveat emptor", this phrase

(5, 2).clue: Benjy, Quentin & Jason Compson narrate 3 of the 4 sections of this Faulkner favorite

(6, 2).clue: Urushiol is the name of the sneaky irritant chemical in this plant

(1, 3).clue: Nestorius caused a Church crisis when he denied that this person was the Theotokos, "God-bearer"

(2, 3).clue: Toni Braxton took over the title role in this show based on a Verdi, Verdi famous opera

(3, 3).clue: "Blind Ambition" was John Dean's personal memoir of his years in the Administration of this President

(4, 3).clue: Virgil wrote, "Omnia vincit amor", this phrase, followed by "et nos cedamus amori" (& let us yield to it)

(5, 3).clue: This Dreiser novel lives up to its title: Clyde plots to murder his pregnant sweetie, she drowns, he's condemned to die

(6, 3).clue: Persian Ivy is this type of plant, like many conifers, that holds its foliage from season to season

(1, 4).clue: In his book "Confessio", this 5th century man has a dream in which the Irish beg him to return

(2, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew presents from the Neil Simon Theater in New York City.) "Welcome to the '60s" & "You Can't Stop the Beat" are 2 of the show-stopping numbers in this smash hit musical

(3, 4).clue: On August 11, 2003 he was on the cover of both Time & Newsweek magazines

(4, 4).clue: The name of this literary device means "a god out of a machine"

(5, 4).clue: Annie is the real first name of this American girl, the title character of an 1878 Henry James story

(6, 4).clue: English Ivy's species name is this, reminiscent of DNA's spiral shape

(1, 5).clue: This brutal barbarian suffered his only defeat in 451 during his invasion of Gaul

(2, 5).clue: After playing the young Judy Garland on TV, Tammy Blanchard played a young stripper in this musical revival

(3, 5).clue: In 1949 Dean Acheson succeeded George Marshall in this Cabinet post

(4, 5).clue: "In situ" means "in place"; this opposite phrase means "in glass", like a test tube, & often precedes "fertilization"

(5, 5).clue: This book by Sherwood Anderson consists of 23 stories about life in a small Ohio town

(6, 5).clue: The name of this southern state precedes "creeper" in a type of ivy

(0, 0).clue: 2 of the 3 state capitals with 5-letter names
